post9547709.msgHTML:
2017 BMW X3 Sports Activity Vehicle

The MY2017 X3 starts production in April 2016. This is likely the last year of production for the current generation F25 X3 before the G01 replaces it. For the last year of production BMW has made a series of changes. Key changes for the MY 2017 X3 include:
  • New, innovative features available including Navigation with iDrive 5.0, Wireless Charging, and WiFi Hotspot
  • Design change for the optional standalone 19" wheel
  • New exterior paint color
  • 3 year 36,000 mile No Cost Schedule Maintenance plan (reduced from 4 year, 48K miles)

2017 BMW F25 X3 SAV Pricing and Ordering Guides:
  • X3 sDrive28i $38,950
  • X3 xDrive28i $40,950
  • X3 xDrive28d $42,450
  • X3 xDrive35i $47,650
  • 2017 F25 BMW X3 pricing guide
  • 2017 F25 BMW X3 ordering guide

Detailed overview of changes for the MY2017 X3



Line & Package changes for the MY2017 X3

M Sport (ZMM)
  • The M leather steering wheel (710), included with M Sport (ZMM), receives a sportier design



Added Stand-Alone Options
  • 2D8 19" Light alloy Star Spoke wheels - style 606 with all-season run-flat tires is now available.
  • 6NW Wireless Charging, including 6WD Wifi Hotspot is now available. This option also includes and an additional USB outlet with up to 2.1 Amp charging current, allowing for faster smartphone charging.

Deleted Stand-Alone Options
  • 2A1 19" Light alloy Double Spoke wheels - style 309 with all-season run-flat tires is no longer available.
  • 6NS Smartphone Integration is no longer available, as the functionality previously included in this option is now available wirelessly with 6NW Wireless Charging.



Paint
  • C29 Chestnut Bronze Metallic is now available
  • B53 Sparkling Brown Metallic is no longer available



Upholstery
  • KCB4 Beige SensaTec is no longer available
  • KCBI Beige/Black SensaTec remains available
  • LUB4 Sand Beige Nevada Leather is no longer available
  • LUBI Sand Beige/Black Nevada Leather remains available

Interior equipment changes
For MY2017, the strap in the right of the luggage compartment is removed from standard equipment.

1.title: FC 120308 Boost Pressure Control

post12550032.msg:
I have a 2013 X3 with the N20 engine that has already been replaced due to the infamous . Last weekend I got another Drivetrain Malfunction warning just as I was leaving town. I turned around and drove the couple of blocks to get home and switch cars for our family trip. When I returned and started it, there was no longer a warning. I scanned it with my Carly app and found  stored in the memory.

It is at the dealer now and they are running a test plan, but the preliminary diagnoses seems to be an issue with the turbo. Has anyone had a similar issue? This motor should have about 12k miles on it at this point, but I suppose they may have just swapped the block and not the turbo? Is there any other common around this? I found the TSB for the N55 engine that points to induction system leaks or restrictions. I haven't seen anything for the N20. 

I've had the X3 for just about 15 months and I regret trading away the reliability of the E90 N52 that I drove for 250k miles. I'm glad, however, that this is a CPO with only 79k right now (but 5 years from service are up in Aug 2018). Once they fix this I am going to carefully consider whether I want to keep it or not.

3.title: Fault P0597 after alignment - could they be related?

post11264225.msg:
Last week I got the alignment corrected for my 2013 X3 28i at a local shop. After collecting the keys when I started the car, the engine light came on. I showed it to the technician and he said it wasn't on when he was test driving the car.

He then connected his scanner and said it was related to engine coolant. He also said sometimes senors go off after servicing so it might be nothing - he then reset the code. I came home and for next 3 days the light didn't come on.

This morning the light again came on. I connected my bluetooth scanner and it picked up P0597. The Torque app reported something to do with Drivetrain and google says "Thermostat Heather Control Circuit Open".

I got the car serviced at the dealer less than 6 months ago and everything was alright (except for slight alignment issue) until I took the car to this workshop for alignment. Is it possible that the workshop broke something? Or just a coincidence? Since it's been 4 days, I am not sure how much help I can get from these guys.

BTW, I am not able to clear the code now using Torque - it says it cleared it but after every restart now the light comes on so wonder if this is more serious. Any pointer on how to fix this problem would be greatly appreciated.

post11266649.msg: Likely one of the sensors for your cooling system has failed and will need to be replaced. You should carefully monitor coolant temperatures to make sure it's not the water pump beginning to fail. As to these codes being related to alignment, I would say about as unrelated as they could be.

post11937937.msg:
I should bring this up for many of you fellow owners...

My CEL came on this past August. AutoZone's complimentary OBD read 0597.. likely failing thermostat. Since I read that BMW Thermostats often die in a stuck-open position, I had a bit of time to remedy this -- certainly didn't want a stuck-open thermostat in Winter.

Eventually gathered Mahle Thermostat TM 25 108, BMW Coolant, & had an indy shop do the install in September. Have since had zero problems with the cooling system.

Going back to the pile of papers I've squirreled away, turns out BMW sent a letter earlier in the year:



Page two covered information on "Previous Customer-pay Repairs - Limited Warranty Extension Reimbursement" with instructions to provide


I mailed my docs to their Reimbursement Center in Dallas, TX. 

Not sure how wide they've extended the scope of this warranty to, so for the moment I'll presume 2013 N20 X3s are covered. Have your service dept check the Covered Component Code to see if it applies to yours. If the thermostat work is already done, reimbursement might be available.
post11937937.msgHTML:
I should bring this up for many of you fellow 2013 X3 2.8i owners...

My CEL came on this past August. AutoZone's complimentary OBD read 0597.. likely failing thermostat. Since I read that BMW Thermostats often die in a stuck-open position, I had a bit of time to remedy this -- certainly didn't want a stuck-open thermostat in Winter.

Eventually gathered Mahle Thermostat TM 25 108, BMW Coolant, & had an indy shop do the install in September. Have since had zero problems with the cooling system.

Going back to the pile of papers I've squirreled away, turns out BMW sent a letter earlier in the year:

...BMW is extending the limited warranty for the engine's:
  • Coolant Thermostat
On the above-referenced vehicle to :
  • 10 years / 120,000 miles as determined by your vehicle's original in-service date
This "component-specific" limited warranty extensions apply to defects in materials or workmanship. This coverage is subject to the same vehicle eligibility requirements, limitations, and exclusions that apply to the BMW New Vehicle Warranty for Passenger Cars and Light Trucks.

Page two covered information on "Previous Customer-pay Repairs - Limited Warranty Extension Reimbursement" with instructions to provide

Repair Order or Invoice
  • Customer name and address
  • Vehicle Identification Number
  • Date of Repair
  • Mileage when repair was performed
  • Itemized breakdown of the labor charges including diagnosis
  • Itemized breakdown of the parts

Proof of Payment
  • Invoice stamped and dated as "PAID"
  • Copy of a cancelled check
  • Copy of a signed credit/debit card receipt
  • Copy of credit/debit card statement

Covered Component Code
B-ELWR 2016 Engine Coolant Thermostat 10Y120M

I mailed my docs to their Reimbursement Center in Dallas, TX.

Not sure how wide they've extended the scope of this warranty to, so for the moment I'll presume 2013 N20 X3s are covered. Have your service dept check the Covered Component Code to see if it applies to yours. If the thermostat work is already done, reimbursement might be available.

post12575750.msg:
I'm just about to close deal on 2012 X3..I'm coming from a dozen years of driving E39's (528i).  Couple of things to consider based on my recent perusal of these cars:

- 11/12 years have N52 I-6 normally aspirated motor (after that you're into 4 or 6 w/turbo).  N20 turbo 4-bangers surprisingly run nicely in these cars but I wonder about longevity- I've driven 2 E39's > 200K and NO motor issues. 

- sport seats are a LOT more supportive than standard.  They can be had in cars with non-sport suspension, tho bit rare I think. 

- M-sport suspension is kinda stiff in my book, gotta drive to assess of course

- backup cam is valuable in this type of car. 

Good luck / Bill

7.title: N55 - smoke from under hood at idle, but not overheating

post12564508.msg:
I'm stumped.  Several times this past month (85F+ average temps), I've stopped at an intersection or in shuffling traffic, and there is noticeable smoke rising from the hood/windshield gap.  A good burning plastic/rubber smell.  Twice I've quickly pulled over and popped the hood but didn't notice anything amiss, went back to driving, and didn't see smoke anymore - even if the initial conditions were met.

Never has the oil temperature even touched the 250 on the gauge, the engine can be either off or idling, and it will happen at random.  The worst happened today when I was stuck in stop-and-go (Atlanta) traffic; after a few minutes of first gear rolling, I stopped where a *huge* bellow of smoke came out the passenger side wheel well and the hood.  Bad enough that I almost thought there was a fire... but then it went right away again.

Is this  the dreaded valve cover leak that I see commonly on the forums, or is it something else entirely?  No fault codes or any noticeable operating issues.  I can photograph specific areas of the engine if that would help diagnose this.  Thanks!

A good burning plastic/rubber smell. Twice I've quickly pulled over and popped the hood but didn't notice anything amiss, went back to driving, and didn't see smoke anymore - even if the initial conditions were met.

Never has the oil temperature even touched the 250 on the gauge, the engine can be either off or idling, and it will happen at random. The worst happened today when I was stuck in stop-and-go (Atlanta) traffic; after a few minutes of first gear rolling, I stopped where a *huge* bellow of smoke came out the passenger side wheel well and the hood. Bad enough that I almost thought there was a fire... but then it went right away again.

Is this the dreaded valve cover leak that I see commonly on the forums, or is it something else entirely? No fault codes or any noticeable operating issues. I can photograph specific areas of the engine if that would help diagnose this. Thanks!

post12564524.msg: I would bet you have a leaky valve cover gasket, oil then burns off on the exhaust.  Open the hood it inspect.  Your probably going to need to remove the engine covers.

post12564620.msg: Definitely check for oil. Also look for any loose plastic or insulation touching the exhaust. Check the belt for rubs. Check the coolant reservoir for cracks or break which would leak steam.
post12564620.msgHTML: Definitely check for oil. Also look for any loose plastic or insulation touching the exhaust. Check the belt for rubs. Check the coolant reservoir for cracks or break which would leak steam.

post10176271.msg:
I had the same clunk described above, which only happened when hitting small bumps or if on a washboard road.  Another giveaway is to have the car off and jiggle the steering wheel back and forth, listening for noise under the hood.  

My indy was initially very hesitant at performing the above adjustment, and talked me into replacing the inner/outer tie rod, and steering shaft in attempt to fix the issue.  He finally agreed to bring in his axle/steering rack guy and one 6-pack later, the noise was gone.  It was a big I told you so, but since the my car is north of 100k right now anyway, I'm happy with preventative maintenance of the other parts.

The steering guy emphasized you need to perform this with both axles unloaded and make very small adjustments at a time.  15k later and no sound has returned.

post10176774.msg:
It is merely an adjustment screw.  If I had a bit more confidence in working on my first electronic steering rack,  I'd have taken it on myself.  Though a 6pack for a professional to do the job is always in the budget!  

If you're experiencing the same symptom, give that E20 an eighth to a quarter turn,  test drive,  then tighten/loosen as you see fit.  Overtightening I'm told can greatly increase the internal wear of the rack.

post10181019.msg: Hi , this nut as people call it is a "damper". To my knowlege every rack and pinion steering has it. It is an  adjustment to stop the rack clunking. It should be adjusted with care as if to much load is put on the rack by the damper it will make it to tight causing the self centering effect not to work.

post9641301.msg: I found the nut in the picture on my 2012 35i. You only need to remove front plastic shield (about 20 screws and two plastic nuts) and it will be easily accessible. It is hard to tell from the picture but the nut faces towards the front of the vehicle and upward at a slight angle. The nut in question is an external torx (e torx), size 20 otherwise known as E20.   I'm going to wait and let others be the Guinea pig before messing with that nut. I say that because there are numerous threads of people complaining of steering rack knock and bmw's solution (even when under warranty) is to replace the whole rack. If the real solution is a simple tightening of a nut, how come bmw has not figured that out?  That would be a significant warranty cost savings for them.

13.title: Active Lane Assist

post12574960.msg:
There appears to be an option on the 2018s providing some minimal level of steering to maintain the vehicle in the center of the lane without driver input to the steering wheel. I am not referring to steering wheel vibration if drifting out of lane but actual control inputs to the steering system. My 2016 just causes the steering wheel to vibrate but all steering control is via me and the steering wheel. The Active Lane Assist option (as it is at least called by Mercedes) is a feature I want, and along with other reasons, I am considering trading my 2016 X3 this year when it is three years old. I just called two local BMW dealers and two Mercedes dealers and have received totally conflicting opinions from their crack salespeople if this feature just vibrates the steering or actually maintains the vehicle in lane if the steering wheel senses it is being touched.

So, is an active lane keeping system available and how does it work? I would be very curious to hear from someone that has this option, assuming it does indeed exist.

post12465238.msg: Yes. All of the factory iDrive functions continue to work as before, including backup camera and parking sensors. The way that the Android system is switched on and off is by pressing the menu button for 3 seconds. You press menu for 3 seconds again and it switches back to factory (with the exception of the backup camera which is automatic regardless of mode).

post12054393.msg:
I also needed a trailer hitch and wiring for lights on my 2015 X3 28d.  The first thing to decide is if you will need the wiring for trailer lights or just the receiver for a bike rack or cargo rack only.  The receiver hitch install is pretty standard for those with tools and a desire to DIY.  The light harness is more complicated because of the CAN/BUS wiring and need for programing.  My local trailer hitch install place wouldn't help me, stating fear of screwing up the computer, so I went to the dealer.  Expensive at $1600, but the piece of mind I received for OEM parts and a warranty covered install was worth it to me.  

Good Luck,
HARFEND

post12092881.msg:
As would be expected, the OEM BMW trailer module that is part of the Invisihitch trailer installation automatically disables the rear parking sensors when it detects trailer light wiring connected to the vehicle.

A bicycle carrier that does not add auxiliary trailer lights would not automatically disable the rear parking sensors and would provide detection alert signals.

The manual center console parking sensor disable push button switch could be used in those cases.

post12542346.msg:
You no doubt have developed a small degree of leakage. Yes you can go to pep boys and get the equivalent coolent...make sure you get the gallon of DISTILLED water to use or mix with the coolent. Warning! DO NOT OVER FILL...or else you'll do yourself more harm then good when your travelling back especially if it's hot in the day. You'll drive around with the two in the trunk until either you service the problem or a shop...what ever you do keep that light off and satisfy the engine with supplying coolent when needed.

post12564904.msg:
Mechanical water pump?  A mechanical water pump's seal is cooled and lubricated by weeping ("leaking***8221 coolant.  A 3rd generation BMW water pump has a weepage collection chamber that also stiffens the WP housing.  The collection chamber is intended to collect the weeped moisture and steam it off invisibly during operation.

Visible water leakage  is a sign of needed inspection and repair/replacement.
post12564904.msgHTML:
Mechanical water pump? A mechanical water pump's seal is cooled and lubricated by weeping ("leaking***8221 coolant. A 3rd generation BMW water pump has a weepage collection chamber that also stiffens the WP housing. The collection chamber is intended to collect the weeped moisture and steam it off invisibly during operation.

Visible water leakage from a BMW 3rd generation WP is a sign of needed inspection and repair/replacement.

post12563020.msg:
Owned my X3 diesel for almost two years and my wife thinks it's the best car we've ever owned.  For urban and suburban driving it feels really zippy due to its low-end torque and I am getting about 32 mpg overall.  However, it is also a great long-distance vehicle.  From the East Coast we did a cross-country trip that went a far north as Calgary and on into British Columbia.  We then drove south to Arizona and Colorado before returning home.  The diesel's range was great for this type of travel and there was never a shortage of filling stations.  It seems that diesel-powered vehicles are popular in rural areas, so it was often at every station.  Currently, we have about 27K miles and the X3 (knock on wood) has not had a single issue.  Oil changes are not really a problem, but two dealers (one in Ohio and the other in Idaho) forgot to add DEF with the oil change.  This, however, is not a huge problem as DEF is cheap and the car provides ample warning that it's needed.  As for special oil, it once was very expensive for BMW diesels, but recently Pennzoil offers a new product selling at Walmart for less than $30 for five quarts.  In the past, one had to buy either BMW branded oil or imported stuff.

As for really cold weather, we live in a snow belt area and the car is wonderful in deep snow (provided one has  ), but we don't experience 40-below temperatures.  As you can see, I am very high on my BMW diesel and consider it the only X3 that interested me.  If one wants a gas model, there are many SUVs (Japanese and otherwise) that I would buy.  But the X3 is one of the few with a great small diesel.  I do agree that the RF   are a shortcoming as are the larger diameter wheels.  The vehicle's ride is much better when I switch to   on 17" wheels.

post12563082.msg: My 2016 28d has been great since I got rid of the runflats.  I average 31.5 mpg driving locally which is rolling hills and no speeds over 45 mph.  I took a roadtrip to east Texas a while back and averaged 39.7 mpg.  I've had zero issues with my car except for a sticking button on one of my remotes.  That was replaced under warranty.  I have put about 25k miles on my car so far.  This is my first diesel car and I have been pleasantly surprised with it's performance.  My car has 32k miles currently and no issues.  I normally drive in "Sport" mode around here because I prefer the shift pattern.  I have discovered no fuel mileage difference regardless of which mode I drive in.   All in all, I have been very satisfied with my diesel and would not be afraid to purchase another one.

post12564608.msg:
I see a lot of comments on run flats.  I can say that the Pirelli Cinturato P7's that came with my used 2016 have no harsh riding issues, with 38,000 miles on them. Last I checked the air pressure it was just 1lb above what's spec'd in the door jam.  The rig has the dynamic handling package including performance control, but 18" wheels (no M-sport option).   Who knows if that makes a difference.  I was really happy to get this combination.  Oversized wheels are for looks only IMHO.  Somebody tested them on a VW I think it was and found little or no handling advantage, maybe a little worse on the really big diameters.  Then there are the weight and $$$ penalties.  To each his or her own!

But having said that I'm likely to go with non-run flats when I need new ones.  Cheaper, lighter, and maybe no more troublesome to deal with if one gets a flat, I won't know for sure until it happens.  I'll carry Slime and a compressor.  Where I live, in the boonies, the downside of run flats is getting them serviced within 50 miles.  It wasn't so clear from the owner's manual that I could go further than that.  I don't know what to think of an owner's manual that equivocates like a politician.

post12566844.msg:
-40 in New Mexico? [Edit - got my locales mixed up - am responding to post from Canada] Sounds more like Fairbanks to me.  You would need a block heater, battery heater, maybe some sort of fuel heater if there is such a thing.  Diesels don't like to warm up either, the newer ones have coolant heating systems to help.  If you really see -40 I wouldn't get a diesel.  

Where I live it can get to -15.  My second car is a 2008 Grand Cherokee with the Mercedes OM642 CRD diesel engine, the pre-Blutec version.  Never needed anything special, might crank slowly but always started.  Generally one should avoid diesel additives, who knows what's in them, and the local fuel supply should be adjusted for temperature.

For diesel fuel always avoid the cheap off-brand gas stations.  A couple of times when I used them, in good weather, morning startup could involve a minute or two of one cylinder not firing.  The BMW owners manual says to not use additives for the diesel X3.  Don't tell the dealer if you do!

Reports I read on the BMW diesels aren't very encouraging.  Carbon buildup, SCR and DPF death, even a cracked piston in one road test car in the UK.  The Mercedes engine has done well.  

Excessive detail follows: At 164,000 miles the CRD engine in the Jeep has not needed major attention, but without the whole diesel fuel additive thing there are fewer things to break. (It has needed a glow plug relay, glow plug control module, one glow plug, and the turbo actuator module,  all things that can be DIY.  An OBD2 reader is essential.)  Certain horror stories about the Mercedes engine in the Jeep installation were fixed as of 2008. (Swirl motor failure, oil cooler gasket leak, both require a lot of labor time to replace.)  The regular Jeep parts have been more of a problem.  The OM642 was only available in 2007 and 2008 MY grand cherokees in the US.  Only 7000 were made in the US.  Shameless self promotion:  Now that I have an X3, the Jeep is for sale.

post12562568.msg:
Hello,
a 3 foot piece of a small hose (like a vacuum hose or tubing) will serve as sound detector hold one end to the ear and the other as a wand collecting the noise. Good advice here; it is possibly a tension bearing carefully find the tension/ pulley and spray some oil at center or rear as some have a plastic cap in the center bolt. If it quiets you found the problem. Only a small amount of spay can oil will do and wipe the oil excess. Be careful with your hands and oil!
Best of luck, Jose

post12559932.msg:
How long did it take you to change out the VC
How hard of a job was it.
What about the valvetronic motor
post12559932.msgHTML:
How long did it take you to change out the VC
How hard of a job was it.
What about the valvetronic motor

post12560650.msg:
I had most of the tools needed for the job so a good 3/8 ratchet with a torx bit set is a must for newer BMWs.
I will say the job wasn't that bad being my first attempt. I got it done in about 6 hours but I tend to be pretty meticulous about removal and install. Some guys have a natural talent at being able to remove fasteners quickly and remembering where they go back during install. 
Fortunately Our F25s have a little more room above the valve cover which gives you a little more access to fasteners in the back that are hell to remove in coupes and sedans. 
I did have to loosen up the plastic cowling near the windshield a bit but not remove it. I also had to remove the passenger side cross-brace above the engine but that was stuff I was hoping I didn't have to do but ended up being pretty easy. 
As far as the valvetronic, that was super easy. The fasteners around it are easy to access as long as you don't have fat 1/4 torx sockets. The valvetronic motor was easy to dismount and mount. Engine started right up with no issues after install.
I would rate the job as medium. A good challenge and well worth saving yourself the $1400 that would be charged to you in labor if you had this done at BMW. 

PS
I did use this video as a really good guide. The video uses an E70 but it's 90% the same.

post9714684.msg:
Welcome to Bimmerfest!  It is my understanding that the original BMW factory warranty runs 4 years/50,000 miles.  The free maintenance now only runs 3 years/36,000 miles (assuming your X3 is a 2017 model).   If you wish to purchase an extended warranty through BMW, you may do so at any time, as long as the original factory warranty is still in effect.  Therefore, you have a lot of time to weigh the pros and cons.

In terms of third party warranties (aftermarket), there are also some pros and cons.  But a lot of people who purchased these warranties came away unhappy.  So please research them carefully.  I would personally not buy one, but YMMV.

post9722288.msg:
A few months before our 2013 X3's factory warranty ran out I purchased an extended "platinum" warranty from Mid-Atlantic AAA, but the warranty is really with a company called "AUL". The warranty goes to 100,000 miles and added 7 years from the date of warranty purchase. The price was $2,247. The deductble is $100 and zero at AAA repair places, and is exclusionary (ie covers everything except a list of not-covered items like cosmetic problems, maintenance, rust, vert tops, earthquakes).

I've had non-dealer 100k mile extended warranties on other cars- Audi, Land Rover, Saab, and each has paid out much more than twice my costs. (Yes - those cars are expensive to fix, eg, I paid $800 for the Audi A4 warranty and the warranty paid out about $8000 over 6 years, including the dealer charging $1500 to fix an AC vent actuator that needed the dash pulled out, and also $1k+ for the infamous control arms wear and creaking.)   And yes for some repairs the warranty company has a contractor visit the shop to be sure the repair is needed but that's only for $1k+ and the approval is quick.

I've found that expensive repairs occur after the factory warranty expires and up to 100k miles. After 100k miles fewer major repairs are needed.

post9722372.msg: If you're interested in a BMW extended warranty then I suggest reaching out to some of the BMW dealers who advertise here.  BMW extended warranties can be sold by any dealer, not just the dealer who you purchased from.  You may need to jump through an extra hoop or two (i.e. overnight them a key fob (which they will return) so that they can read it out and verify your mileage), but if you want a BMW extended warranty then it may be worth it.

post12548386.msg:
Many have said if you replace battery with OEM or aftermarket there is no need to register if and only it's the same CCA and AH specs. The car will have the necessary battery specs for the IBS already.
However if you get a different spec battery you will need to register the IBS to tell it how to correctly charge your battery. 
I replaced my battery with higher CCA and AH and registered with Carly app. 
It will be a lot cheaper to replace your battery and purchase Carly app than having dealer do it for you if you're mechanically inclined.

post12548850.msg: The ECU/IBS needs the battery adaptations reset.  The IBS is a Coulombs tracker - Coulombs per second is amperes current.  Any old battery will 'work'.  For best service life and performance of an expensive AGM it must be registered, not least to reset the adaptations.

post12558534.msg:
My parent's X3 had their battery replaced by an indy and I'm fairly certain they forgot to register it. Didn't realize how important registering was until my parent's were stranded outside of a shopping center in 100 degree weather and I had to come rescue them. The car actually froze up for about 2 hours and would't respond to anything. Wouldn't lock/unlock, wouldn't start, turn signals stayed on partially. All this persisted even after crawling inside the car and disconnecting and reconnecting the new battery. 
This began happening more and more frequently over the span of about 6 months or 3 months after the battery had been replaced. 
I had the car inspected by BMW thinking it was a faulty ECU or electrical issue and the tech said the car did not show that the new battery had been registered in the car's system. After a $125 BMW diagnostic fee, I took the car back to the indy and they claimed that they did register but would register it "again" for free. 
No issues since (almost 1 year since the issue). 
Get it registered is the moral of this story and sometimes saving a little money at an indy doesn't always pay off in the end especially with these electronics.

post12538878.msg:
28 PSI is low.  What does the decal on the door jamb say?    On our G01 X3 it's 32 PSI front, and 35 PSI rear.  I haven't seen 20-something PSI as a recommended tire pressure since the 1990's.

Have you measured your tread depths in the circumferential channels?  Tread depth gauges are about $4 at any auto parts store.

  RFT's have a better reputation than most other RFT's.  What you have is probably as good as it gets with RFT's.  

Our G01 has OE non-RFT's and BMW throws in a mini-spare (on an aluminum rim) and a jack for free of you get the non-RFT's (only available on the non-M Sport 30i).

post12539096.msg:
The G01 X3 has a spare tire hole.  The F25 doesn't, which is why we didn't buy one.   My spare is a 135/10-18, 26.5" tread diameter.  The car's   are 245/50-19, 28.6" tread diameter.    

The new xDrive software  detects that a spare is on and moves the power to the other axle and turns off the traction control, preventing damage to the clutches in the transfer case and brakes.  The owner's manual says only that there will be weird handling characteristics when the spare is installed.  It doesn't limit the distance you can drive with the spare installed.

The hub and bolt hole pattern might be different between the F25 and the G01.   sells a spare & jack kit for he F25 with a 27.1" tread diameter.   It's a "jury rig," requiring a centering ring to match the rim's hole to the car's hub.  It's a good idea to buy spare centering rings.  They get bent (aluminum) or torn up (plastic).



Our X3 is our family road trip car.  So, not having a spare was a deal breaker.   Othewise, we could  end up like these guys:







I carry an aftermarket spare in my F10 535i.  It hogs up trunk space.  But, the worst thing is not having a flat floor for runs to Sam's Club (problem solved by the arrival of the G01 X3). Fortunately, a large suitcase fits on top of the spare.

BMW's slowly learning their lesson.    The current 5, 7, X1, X2, X3, X4, and X5 offer optional spares and a hole under the cargo area/trunk floor to store them... except in hybrids and X5's  with the 3rd row seats. Bimmerzone.com

post12547320.msg:
This will raise all kind of comments.
I don't recommend anyone ever not doing what BMW says to do in regard to safety issues like tire pressure.
I run my RFT's at 28lbs all around. Simply put, I drive the x3 through a wet area on the street and look to see how the contact patch looks. I also look across the top of the tire to see if the tire is dished concave or convex. Concave would indicate tire pressure to high. Convex, tire pressure to low.
I adjust until I see that the tire is wearing flat. I've been adjusting tire pressure this way for many years and have had really good success with tire wear and ride comfort. If you look at the side wall you'll a maximum load rating. The max load on my   far out weighs the weight of the X3 so it makes no sense to run the pressure at or near max. 
Just my two cents.
Do not try this at home. Must be 18 to play. Results may vary from person to person.

post12547960.msgHTML: I wonder why BMW doesn't recommend tire rotation. At least in my manual they dont.

post12548298.msg:
Typically BMW has always advised against rotation as the wear pattern varies quite a bit when comparing front to rear  - typically BMW cars have significantly higher value of negative camber on rear suspension than most cars- that aids in enabling a heavy vehicle handle well. 



I’ve been driving RWD BMW sedans for a long time- I have always done front/rear rotation at about 5k mileage intervals w/o any averse issues.  It gives me about 20% increase in overall tire life- 



Next time you’re out driving observe the rear wheels on the cars directly in front of you...a Bimmer will almost always present visibly less ‘vertical’ rear  ; more neg rear camber.

'I’ve been driving RWD BMW sedans for a long time- I have always done front/rear rotation at about 5k mileage intervals w/o any averse issues. It gives me about 20% increase in overall tire life'

I see this explanation often, and am not trying to single out your post, but I include more data in my calculations.
Assuming a tire is $250,and may last 30k miles, you would rotate 5 times in addition to the initial install if done at 5k intervals . If you save a high of 20% increase in wear,  that's $50,or $200 a set.
So, is it worth interrupting 5 days of your life to save up to $200 over 3 or 4 years?
I obviously don't rotate, but I do maintain pressure and inspect often.

That's what I was looking for in the beginning and found out myself during reading thru the help here from others.
I did some back and forth with my new radio and I managed it and I hear the sound now.
It's also switching now between radio and aux when I press the "mode" button.
The clue was to go to the left back when in the cd player menu.
There is no day where you dont learn new things

Thanks to everyone here

post12473342.msg:
I bet those RFT's of yours had more wear on the inside and outside edges.   

Radial ties are called that because the cords in the sidewalls are all in the radial direction.  Cords resist stretching, but only in the direction they are.   So, in a radial tire  the sidewall can stretch considerably in the circumferential direction (90 degrees from the radial  direction).  The sidewall stretching in the circumferential  direction is what allows the tread to conform to the flat surface of the pavement, improving traction and durability.

With the old bias-ply   the sidewalls didn't stretch as much, since the cords were oriented in multiple directions.  This limited how much the sidewalls could stretch, which prevented the tread from conforming to the pavement.  The tread would buckle inward concentrating reaction force and wear around the edges of the contact patch.   This would concentrate the wear around the inside and outside of the tread.

I managed to get my LS2's to wear evenly, by over inflating them by about 15%.  After 30k miles, the tread depths were still from 5.5/32nds to 7/32nds inch.    But, the ride was horrible.  

The G01 X3 30i offers 19" non-RFT's  as an option, for free.   They also throw in a $150 spare tire and jack for free with the non-RFT's.

post12490872.msg:
I understand that necessity. 

However, tread life is sometimes less a matter of RFT vs GoFlat and more about tread compound and tire design. Typically   fitted as BMW original equipment are rated Ultra-High Performance. Usually means softer rubber compounds and tread design to maximize traction and handling ... vs other tire design & ratings intended to produce longer tread life ... e.g. harder rubber compounds etc. So the latter may offer longer tread life but may have to sacrifice traction/handling. 

Check out the Uniform Tire Grading article at   - useful information.
